Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Social isolation during COVID-19: Effects on fear learning and implications for trauma

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: In response to COVID-19, people across the United States have experienced extreme and abrupt shifts in their level of daily contact with others, forcing many people into a state of social isolation. This project examines whether the experience of social isolation amplifies the development of harmful and persistent fears in humans. The research further tests if social isolation reduces the ability to eliminate those fears once learned. This study utilizes a unique situational event (social isolation due to COVID-19), which cannot be replicated in the laboratory, to provide rare insight into how social isolation heightens the development of fear and if experiences of social connection can reverse these effects. This research will contribute to the growing understanding of the effects of social isolation on increasing fears and influencing the developmental course of trauma; it may also provide simple strategies to mitigate those effects.<br/><br/>Research suggests that social isolation may influence long-term trauma by directly influencing fear learning processes. Socially isolated animals exhibit increases in fear responses that persist even when a threat is no longer present, are more likely to develop PTSD-like symptoms following trauma. Similarly, research suggests that socially isolated humans are at a greater risk of developing PTSD. To date, however, no work has directly examined the impact of extreme social isolation on fear learning in humans. Preliminary data suggests that feeling socially isolated appears to lead to persistent fears and poorer fear extinction, although these effects may be eliminated when individuals are reminded of their social support during fear extinction. This project will evaluate these hypotheses by sampling people from across the U.S. living in places where some form of ‘Stay at Home’ order is in place. The research examines whether the extreme situational social isolation brought about by COVID-19 leads to increased development of fear associations for neutral images paired with negative affective stimuli. The study also examines whether a two-week social connection intervention, during which individuals will be asked to do positive things for others to promote feelings of connectedness, improves fear extinction and decreases the development of fear associations in those most severely isolated. The findings of this work have the potential to shed light on how social isolation influences the course of trauma and reveal simple, low-cost, and accessible interventions to reduce this trauma that can be used immediately and in the future to ease the harmful side effects of necessary measures to address COVID-19 and similar events.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first of its kind to examine the impact of social isolation on the ways in which humans learn to be afraid, this project examined whether the social isolation brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic influenced how negative and fearful associations were formed and reduced. While no effects of objective social isolation (having little or no in-person contact with others) were found, results did show that perceived social isolation, also known as loneliness, indeed has powerful effects on fear associations. Specifically, greater loneliness led to poorer extinction of negative and fearful associations, suggesting that those who are more lonely may be less able to reduce the occurrence of fearful or negative affective responding even following a procedure designed to enable them to do so.

These results provide an important advance in scientific understanding, for they are the first to come from a well-powered examination of the effects of loneliness on the development of fearful associations. In combination with several preliminary investigations showing that loneliness impairs Pavlovian fear extinction in the lab, the findings of this work provide strong evidence for the never-before examined extinction-impairing effects of loneliness. In combination with other recent research demonstrating the beneficial role of social connection during fear learning processes, these project outcomes add to the growing understanding of the critical role of our social relationships in how we learn to be afraid.

In addition to contributing to scientific understanding, the results of this work also contribute insight into the role of loneliness in the persistence of trauma, negative affect, and fear as well as factors that may impact methods of intervention to reduce such experiences. Specifically, extinction processes serve as the basis of some of the most successful interventions to reduce pathological or unnecessary fears (i.e., exposure therapies or exposure based procedures), and thus, by revealing that loneliness may impair these interventions, this work brings to light the need for future research and possible different methods of intervention to reduce fear in lonely individuals. Importantly, during the course of this work we found that a two-week intervention designed to promote social connectedness following extinction, during which participants were simply asked to do three nice acts for others each week, was effective in reducing loneliness. Although this intervention did not mitigate the effects of loneliness on extinction of fear associations, these findings are notable, for they suggest that such an intervention may be useful if implemented prior to extinction procedures, as opposed to following, reducing the feelings of loneliness that impair extinction outcomes. Regardless of their potential to inform methods to benefit individuals' associative learning, these findings also suggest a relatively easy and non-invasive method to reduce loneliness, which has been linked to poor mental and physical health outcomes and decreased overall well-being. Therefore, the outcomes of this project not only shed light on the need for increased understanding of the influence of loneliness on the course of trauma, negative affect, and fear in order to develop more effective interventions for those who are lonely, but also indicate potential avenues for improving well-being in lonely individuals via the social connectedness intervention used here.

Overall, the outcomes of this project represent an important step forward in understanding both the role of loneliness in the ways in which we learn to be afraid as well as how this knowledge can contribute to improving interventions targeted at reducing fear or improving well-being in lonely individuals.
